Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
>  
>
>>the fitness at the end of both complexifying and blended runs is
>>*worse* than the random initial population.
>>
>>    
>>
Well it's not worse but it pretty bad. The population starts out with no 
connections and hence all genomes score 0 in the first few generations 
until good conenctions are found. This was found to give similar results 
to starting with a small proportion of input-output neurons connections

>
>> <>This is a traditional NEAT run in Colin's domain. The max fitness for
>
>>this domain is 260,
>>
yep.

>> <> I believe. For the first few hundred generations,the population 
>> improves to about 80, but for the next several*thousand* generations, 
>> the max and average fitness for the population gets worse and worse, 
>> ending up essentially as good as the initial random population (~10). 
>> This isn't about simpler or more complex individuals performing 
>> better or worse. This is about the entire population getting *worse* 
>> throughout the run. It certainly seems to me that this is not the way 
>> NEAT is supposed to work.
>
>
>That definitely is a bit odd.  Colin, what was the number of 
>generations of stagnation before a species was cut?  It looks like 
>species were dying off pretty quickly there is that's really the 
>underlying explanation for the downward trend.
>  
>
The species 'drop off age' was set to 200 generations. I still beleive 
that the drop in population fitness is due to the phenomena I described, 
that is:

1) A rising species compatibilty threshold caused by the quickly rising 
complexity. This causes like species to be combined into fewer species.

2) SharpNEAT culling fit species when they reach the drop off age.

3) SharpNEATs current crossover technique which is very likely causing 
complexity to rise far quicker than in other NEAT implementations and 
thus exacerbating (1).


If I were to change (2) so that I focus in on the fittest species (as 
does original NEAT) then the fitness would (should) not ever drop. But 
as I say, I would prefer to cull species once they had not improved for 
some time, even if they are the fittest. I am willing to admit that the 
culling age should perhaps be a lot greater for the fittest species, 
since the culling's primary purpose is to discard of the numerous new 
topologies, the bulk of which will probably be no good. Culling the 
fittest species after 200 generations might be being too eager.

But the principle remains that I recon it is still valid to give up on 
the best topology if it hasn;t improved and to move on to another area 
of the search space. If we keep complexity in check then we might then 
see another rise in fitness following a dip (which we do see in small 
amounts, right?) as we move around different areas in the search space 
and give up on each of them in turn.

The question is, when do you give up? Or is it preferable to do what 
original NEAT does and focus in on the current best species and leave it 
to the operator to give up and re-start the search? I suppose if you 
look at nature then the fittest species are never given up on - a local 
optimum is better than nothing, but then nature has a far large 
population to work with when trying get out of local optima.

Colin.
